desc: BIRC3, an anti-apoptotic protein, is altered in various cancers.

BIRC3 (baculoviral IAP repeat containing 3, also known as cIAP2) is a member of the inhibitor of apoptosis (IAP) family of proteins that is involved in cell death and survival as well as immune signaling (PMID: 16382159, 19464198, 20651737). It is a modulator of NFκB activity and an inhibitor of apoptosis, containing a caspase-recruiting domain (CARD), commonly found in apoptotic factors, and a RING finger domain which allows for ligation of ubiquitin to substrates of BIRC3 (PMID: 8548810, 20651737). BIRC3 activates the canonical NFκB pathway following tumor necrosis factor (TNF)α binding to TNFR1 (TNF receptor 1). Receptor activation triggers assembly of a complex wherein BIRC3 mediates ubiquitination of RIPK1 (Receptor-interacting serine/threonine-protein kinase 1) and other factors, resulting in derepression of NFκB (PMID: 20651737, 11907583). BIRC3 also activates non-canonical NFκB signaling by mediating ubiquitination of NIK (NF­κB-­inducing kinase) (PMID: 20651737, 11907583). Additionally, BIRC3 is proposed to directly ubiquitinate caspases 3 and 7 (PMID: 20651737). BIRC3 and its homolog, BIRC2 (cIAP1), are functionally redundant in preclinical model systems, but also have non-overlapping expression patterns suggesting distinct biological functions (PMID: 20651737, 21430708). BIRC3 is infrequently mutated in human cancers but is amplified in some lung cancers (PMID: 12651874).
